title: Ghulam Ali concert nixed over Pakistan firing at border: Aditya Thackeray
text:
A day after the Shiv Sena forced the cancellation of Pakistani ghazal maestro Ghulam Ali's shows in Mumbai and Pune, Yuva Sena chief Aditya Thackeray justified the action.
Aditya, who is Shiv Sena president Uddhav Thackeray's elder son, said that entertainment and cultural programmes could not go on with tension at the border.
Speaking on the sidelines of a function on Thursday, Aditya said it was wrong to hold programmes in Mumbai, featuring Pakistani artistes when Pakistan was relentlessly firing across the border. He added that it was their opinion that such entertainment programmes should not be held under such circumstances.
While the state government, in which the Shiv Sena is the BJP's junior partner, had offered to provide security to Ghulam Ali, Aditya said instead of securing the singer, it was necessary to beef up security at the border for Indians.
The Shiv Sena opposes cultural and sports ties with Pakistan over sponsoring of terrorism and crime in India. In October 1991, former MNS MLA Shishir Shinde, who was then in the Shiv Sena, had dug up the pitch at the Wankhede stadium to protest an India-Pakistan cricket match which was to be played there.
In 2013, the Shiv Sena had protested against the inclusion of Pakistani players in a hockey match, forcing the organisers to remove them from the team. It also opposed the Centre's plans to grant a visa to cricketer Javed Miandad and charged that this would be akin to "laying out a red carpet" for underworld don Dawood Ibrahim, whose daughter is married to Miandad's son.
The Sena had also castigated Narendra Modi, who was then the BJP's prime ministerial nominee, for allowing the Pakistan cricket team to play a match on Indian soil at Rajkot.
